poem:
### Liberation Day

A rose garden,  
union echoes,  
Main Street murmurs—  
Trump's tongue  
weighs tribute  
among rust-edged  
dreams of empire.  

Promises,  
windswept paper  
fluttering in  
autumn air,  
declare victory  
in shades of  
moot—  
logic's ghost  
wanders  
without map or compass.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "The Guardian view on Donald Trump’s tariff ultimatum: tribute for access to America’s empire | Editorial When Donald Trump stood before union auto workers in the Rose Garden he declared “Liberation Day”, promising to stand up for Main Street. Whether that pledge will be fulfilled is moot. He will declare victory either way. What the US president offered was not just an economic programme, but an imperial one. Mr Trump’s logic, if it exists, lies". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: The Guardian view on Donald Trump’s tariff ultimatum: tribute for access to America’s empire | Editorial When Donald Trump stood before union auto workers in the Rose Garden he declared “Liberation Day”, promising to stand up for Main Street. Whether that pledge will be fulfilled is moot. He will declare victory either way. What the US president offered was not just an economic programme, but an imperial one. Mr Trump’s logic, if it exists, lies
